title: RBS shares drop after US demands $13bn settlement
text:
Tip : Use comma (,) to separate multiple quotes. Learn more... 
Fri, Jul 3, 2015, 19:04 BST - UK Markets closed RBS shares drop after US demands $13bn settlement By Tim Wallace | Telegraph – 59 minutes ago 359.30 -6.80 
Lawyers in the US say the bank could owe $13bn, but RBS (LSE: RBS.L - news ) does not think the bill will climb that high 
More than £800m has been wiped off Royal Bank of Scotland following claims it could face a $13bn (£8.3bn) bill over the sale of toxic mortgage assets in the years leading up to the financial crisis. 
Despite the bank, which is 79pc owned by the British taxpayer, not expecting the final bill to climb to such an enormous level, its stock closed 1.9pc lower at 359.3p on Friday. 
RBS's lawyers will view the $13bn figure, which was set out in court documents filed in the US, as an opening demand from claimants. 
The potential cost was outlined in filings made in a New York court by lawyers acting for the government-backed Federal Housing Finance Agency (FHFA), in a case which also involved Japanese bank Nomura . 
RBS is facing cases in New York and Connecticut, and the FHFA’s lawyer, Philippe Selendy, said in a filing that another case “extrapolates to a judgment in the Connecticut action of nearly $13bn”. 
In the filings the lawyers said they did not expect RBS to be able to afford such a “massive exposure”. 
However, RBS is not thought to be taking the $13bn figure as a serious threat, and the British bank’s lawyers are expected to be likely to view it more as a demand from the FHFA than a reasonable court judgment. 
Previously RBS has set aside more than £2bn in provisions to cover the cost of the case, though it believes the final cost will be above that level. 
Chief executive Ross McEwan has said he hopes the case can be settled this year, though the bank cannot set the timing of court proceedings. 
Legal cases of this scale do not always reach a final conclusion in court, with each sides able to use the proceedings to set out there case and demands ahead of private negotiations and settlements out of court. 
The $13bn sum is a worst case scenario that would only be applied if the Connecticut case went to court, RBS settled and the amount was agreed upon. 
A judge has already sided with the FHFA in the New York case, in a ruling that could allow the FHFA to recover around $450m. RBS is expected to appeal the decision. 
It comes at a critical time for RBS. Chancellor George Osborne announced last month that he plans to start selling off the UK government’s stake later this year. 
The bank also hopes to return to profit in 2016 for the first time since its £46bn bailout in 2008. It announced a £3.5bn annual loss for last year. 
RBS has already taken a £400m hit for PPI compensation, £430m for US fines related to foreign exchange rigging , and another £444m of conduct and litigation charges in the fourth quarter of last year. 
RBS declined to comment.
